description: __DATA segment tail provenance: mapping every byte in segment-relative 0xDC50..0xDFFF

sections.name: __bss
sections.note: No file backing (S_ZEROFILL); zero-initialized at runtime by loader

sections.name: __common
sections.note: No file backing (S_ZEROFILL); zero-initialized at runtime by loader

regions.name: inter_section_alignment_padding
regions.cause: __bss section alignment 2^8=256 requires VA 0xF80C1D00; __data ends at VA 0xF80C1C50; gap = 0xB0 = 176 bytes
regions.content: GNU Emacs ChangeLog text (Oct 1986, Richard Mlynarik at MIT)
regions.runtime_fate: Unmapped gap between sections; not zeroed by loader, not referenced by code

regions.name: segment_file_padding_in_bss_range
regions.cause: Segment filesize (0xE000=57344) extends past __data section (0xDC50=56400) into __bss VA range; __bss is S_ZEROFILL with offset=0, so these file bytes are inert padding
regions.content: GNU Emacs ChangeLog text (Oct 1986, Richard Mlynarik at MIT)
regions.runtime_fate: Overwritten with zeros by Mach-O loader when __bss is initialized

tail.content_summary: All 944 bytes are 100% printable ASCII: GNU Emacs ChangeLog entries from October 1986 by Richard Mlynarik. This is stale linker padding â€” the ld(1) tool did not zero the gap between __data and the segment file boundary, leaving whatever was in the link-time object file buffer.
tail.conclusion: No i860 code, no data structures, no dispatch tables. Every byte is accounted for as linker/alignment artifact.
